Award.AbstractNarration: The Combined Array for Research in Millimeter Astronomy (CARMA) was formed from the merger of three telescope arrays supported by the Division of Astronomical Science's University Radio Observatories (URO) Program: Caltech's Owens Valley Radio Observatory (OVRO) array of six 10.4-meter-diameter telescopes, the Berkeley Illinois Maryland Association (BIMA) array of nine 6.1-meter-diameter telescopes, and the University of Chicago's Sunyaev-Zeldovitch Array of eight 3.5-meter-diameter telescopes. CARMA currently achieves resolutions as high as 0.2 arcseconds at a wavelength of 1mm and, due to its heterogeneous combination of telescope diameters, provides excellent imaging over a wide range of angular scales. Science enabled by CARMA covers a broad range of astronomical topics, including star formation and molecular clouds, studies of external galaxies, and the investigation of solar system objects. CARMA is a pathfinder for the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) and a pipeline for training experts in the field of millimeter interferometry to take full advantage of ALMA's capabilities for US astronomy. Users outside the CARMA collaboration receive 30% of all observing time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Combined Array for Research in Millimeter Astronomy (CARMA) consited of six 10.4-meter-diameter telescopes, nine 6.1-meter-diameter telescopes, and eight 3.5-meter-diameter telescopes.   With CARMA, we addressed a broad range of science with observations of gas (molecular, atomic and ionized) and dust in a wide range of objects in the Universe: from the formation of stars to the formation of galaxies and creation of structure in the early universe. The award supported the astronomical observations conducted with the array and the data analysis and dissemination of the results.  At Illinois, we focused on dust polarization observations of star forming regions on 100 AU size scales to better understand the origin of planets, polarization observations toward high mass star forming regions to understand the role of the magnetic field during the early stages of collpase, polarization toward evolved stars to understand stellar evolution, molecular line surveys of nearby molecular clouds, including Serpens, Orion A, and Perseus to probe the contribution of turbulence in structures that form stars, and a large molecular gas survey of 125 nearby galaxies to better understand the star formation process on galaxy size-scales.

In addition, the Illinois group continues to work on data preservation: 1) oversight and management of activities related to the CARMA archive and web-based data access interface to the CARMA user community, in regard to both software development, hardware infrastructure, and system administration services; 2) joint evaluation of options for long-term archiving in the post-CARMA era; and 3) safe curation and preservation of CARMA data at multiple backup levels using diverse media.

Finally, CARMA trained and educated graduate students and postdocs and as we ended science production.  We are still concentrating on this aspect of our misson, especially as we transfer to using ALMA as our main science observatory.  One of the unique aspects of CARMA is that we have established groups (professorial faculty, research faculty, postdocs, and students) at each institution. These groups, typically of order 5-10 people in size, provide learning and mentoring environments for the students and postdocs that give them support and encouragement at many levels. Each group typically has junior and senior graduate students and postdocs so a significant amount of learning occurs in peer to peer interactions. The professorial and research faculty participate in teaching and mentoring all of the students and postdocs in the groups. As a part of mentoring, training, and career development, we encouraged graduate students and postdocs to be first authors on CARMA proposals and carry the data forward to publication. The majority of CARMA projects were led by students and postdocs.
